ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about astronomy and the cosmos
Good introduction to the concepts of time, relativity, cosmology, and many other things I didn't realize existed
I learned a lot more about how science works in academia and how research works.
I grew my general understanding of astrophysical and cosmological principles from almost zero to sound grasp.

I developed a deeper understanding of larger concepts within physics/astrophysics, such as special and general relativity, black holes, dark matter, dark energy, and even time itself. I also gained insight into how science is conducted, and the intricacies (and shortcomings) of scientific research and academia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I thought that this course had a really interesting subject matter. But I have a few problems with it:
1. Our instructors' presence on Canvas was very disorganized, which made it hard to follow when assignments were due, and what they were actually asking of us. For instance, during one of our last classes, a classmate asked when a poster was due and our instructor responded, "tomorrow." The assignment had never been posted on Canvas. This led to a lot of last-minute preparation and cramming
2. Our "reading quizzes" asked far too much of the students. We, many of us being non-physics majors, would be assigned several hours' worth of reading on astrophysics and then quizzed on the minutae of it (I.e. what does this term mean).  Even though I genuinely did all of the readings, I found myself not scoring well on the quizzes simply because of the nature of them
3. We were asked to complete a 20-page paper with pretty much no scaffolding. When my classmates and I expressed our confusion about how to even approach a task as daunting as this, our instructor expressed her shock that we had never written a 20-page paper, but did not really offer help or advice

Strengths - interesting and engaging
Weaknesses - sometimes the organization was poor and it was easy to feel like you're not getting it

Strengths: incredibly interesting discussions and projects, productive office hours 
Weaknesses: physics portion during the second half of the semester was nearly impossible to understand and I was not able to relate it to what we were learning about

This course takes a uniquely conversational and colloquial approach to scientific concepts. It thrived in its encouragement of discussion, questioning, and collaboration. The instructor's office hours, while limited, were convenient for me and always were helpful. While it didn't necessarily feel like a science course (because it is not lecture-based), I found every class meeting interesting and engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Maybe. I think the subject matter is really interesting. However, it is pretty poorly-organized, and you have to do a lot of self-teaching
Yes; I took the course because the name sounded interesting, and I came out of it knowing so much more than I expected both in terms of the universe and the field of astronomy.
Yes, I think a first year seminar is a perfect class to take, and I found this one really interesting because it's something I might never get to learn as much about again.
Yes. The course was soincredibly interesting and Profesor Urry makes even more so.

I would absolutely recommend this class to any student with any interest in astrophysics or space in general. The material was intriguing, the conversations were energetic and thought-provoking, and the work was interesting (even at times entertaining).
